critique: Let's analyze this executive order. It seems to be focused on requiring agencies to prepare a Statement of Energy Effects when undertaking certain actions. This appears to be an effort to improve the quality of agency decision-making by providing more useful energy-related information. It doesn't seem to directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, or social inclusion. However, it does touch on economic regulation by requiring agencies to consider the effects of regulations on energy supply, distribution, and use. It's difficult to place this on the ideological spectrum, but it seems to lean slightly towards deregulation by emphasizing the effects of government regulations on energy. Therefore, I will give it a slightly negative score on economic regulation. The order doesn't seem to have a strong ideological tilt, so I'll give it a neutral score there. It also doesn't seem to affect executive power, federalism, immigration, national security, or social inclusion, so I'll give it neutral scores on those axes as well. After further consideration, the order seems more focused on improving the efficiency and information gathering of the federal government rather than promoting deregulation. Therefore, I will revise the economic regulation score to be more neutral.
